Markowitz portfolio model

What are we doing

About the model

Markowitz's portfolio theory will help both experienced and novice investors make the right decision about the best placement of available funds. After all, every self-respecting person should competently manage their own money resources.


Markowitz's approach to the formation of a portfolio of securities gives the investor the opportunity to simultaneously maximize the expected return and minimize the risk.

Markowitz portfolio theory

Markowitz portfolio theory is based on several very important assumptions. Under these assumptions a portfolio is considered to be efficient if no other portfolio offers a higher expected return with the same or lower risk.

The maximum benefit

Investors are rational and behave in a manner as to maximise their utility with a given level of income or money.

Free access

Investors have free access to fair and correct information on the returns and risk.

Market efficiency

The markets are efficient and absorb the information quickly and perfectly.

Risks

Investors are risk averse and try to minimise the risk and maximise return.

Decisions

Investors base decisions on expected returns and variance or standard deviation of these returns from the mean.

High income

Investors choose higher returns to lower returns for a given level of risk.
